metadata.case_name: Assessee Company v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: The assessee is a Limited Company appointed as Managing Agent of Shree Ramesh Cotton Mills Ltd. (100% subsidiary, referred to as managed company) by agreement dated 30-12-1946.

Under the agreement, appellant entitled to fixed office allowance of Rs. 1,000 per mensem plus commission at 12.5% of net profits, additional 1.5% on purchases of cotton and equal on sales of cloth and yarn.

Managed company suffered losses in relevant years; 12.5% commission nil; commission on purchases and sales: Rs. 38,719 for 1956-57 and Rs. 1,963 for 1957-58; plus fixed office allowance Rs. 12,000 each year; totals Rs. 50,719 and Rs. 13,963.
Managed company's accounting year ends 30th December; appellant's ends 30th June.
Clause 2(e) of agreement: commission due yearly on 31st December or date accounts close; payable immediately after annual accounts passed by Board, Auditors and in General Meeting.
Annual General Meetings of managed company: November 24, 1955 and July 21, 1956.
Commission amounts due on 31st December 1954 and 31st December 1955; payable after November 24, 1955 and July 21, 1956 respectively.
Appellant relinquished managing agency commission for 1956-57 by Board resolution dated April 4, 1955; for 1957-58 by resolution dated June 19, 1956 (after due dates but before payable dates).
Appellant stated managed company suffering heavy losses; relinquished commission and fixed office allowance as not proper to charge.

Income-tax Officer included Rs. 50,719 and Rs. 13,963 in appellant's total income for 1956-57 and 1957-58; viewed fixed allowance as to recoup expenses, relinquishment ex-gratia; commission accrued on due basis.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal affirmed ITO.
Tribunal: commission due on last day of managed company's accounting year; payment postponement inconsequential; relinquishment after due inconsequential.

Appellant claimed relinquished amount as permissible expenditure u/s 10(2)(xv); rejected by Tribunal as not benefiting appellant (managed co. loss Rs. 14,95,221 at end 1955; relinquishment weakened appellant).
Tribunal referred two questions to Calcutta High Court at instance of appellant.

High Court answered questions against assessee, in favour of respondent; accrual complete within managed company's year; no relinquishment before due; unilateral act; not for commercial expediency u/s 10(2)(xv). Judgment dated January 28, 1964 in Income-tax Reference No. 104 of 1960.
Appellant maintains mercantile system of accounting.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the sums of Rs. 50,719 and Rs. 13,963 foregone by assessee by Directors' resolutions dated 4-4-1955 and 19-6-1956 were liable to be included in its total income for accounting years ending 30-6-1955 and 30-6-1956?
If answer to Q1 affirmative, whether assessee entitled to claim allowance of equivalent amount as expenditure under Section 10(2)(xv) of Indian Income Tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Amounts never received by appellant but relinquished; no tax liability arises.
Relinquishment of amounts should be construed as permissible expenditure under Section 10(2)(xv).

respondent_arguments.text: Fixed office allowance to recoup expenses; relinquishment ex-gratia. Commission became due at end of managed company's year; foregone after due, taxable on accrual basis.
Commission due on last day of managed company's accounting year; postponement of payment inconsequential; relinquishment after accrual inconsequential.
Relinquishment not for benefit of appellant; managed company loss Rs. 14,95,221; not permissible u/s 10(2)(xv).
Accrual complete within managed company's accounting year; no relinquishment before amount due; unilateral act; not for commercial expediency.

court_reasoning.text: Commission became due on 31 Dec 1954 and 1955 per clause 2(e); fixed allowance entitled; income accrued on those dates despite deferred payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Postponement of payment does not affect accrual; income accrues when due; vested right arises.

court_reasoning.text: Section 4(1)(b)(i): total income includes income accruing/arising/deemed to during year. Accrue means to come as accession, fall due.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accrual not equated with receipt; distinct in Section 4(1)(a) and (b).

court_reasoning.text: Appellant follows mercantile system: credits for amounts due when legally due, before receipt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits credited though not realised show accrual.

court_reasoning.text: Cites Shoorji Vallabhdas: if income results, tax on accrual or receipt; unilateral give up after accrual does not erase tax liability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unlike Shoorji where agreement for lesser remuneration before accrual; here unilateral after accrual.

court_reasoning.text: No substance in contentions; amounts includible.

holdings.text: Sums foregone liable to be included in total income as accrued on due dates despite relinquishment after accrual.
Relinquishment not permissible expenditure under Section 10(2)(xv).

precedents_cited.case_name: Indermani Jatia v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mercantile system records credits/debits when due, not on cash basis.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City I v. Messrs Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Income tax on accrual or receipt if income results; unilateral give-up after accrual taxable; distinguished as here no prior agreement for lesser sum.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Total income includes accrued income; allowance for business expenditure; reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding High Court; amounts accrued and taxable despite relinquishment; no deduction under Section 10(2)(xv).

key_quotes.text: The dictionary meaning of the word 'accrue' is to come as an accession, increment, or produce; to fall to one by way of advantage; to fall due.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines accrual for tax purposes under Section 4(1)(b).

key_quotes.text: The accrual of an income is not to be equated with the receipt of the income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes accrual from receipt in mercantile system.

key_quotes.text: Where income has, in fact, been received and is subsequently given up in such circumstances that it remains the income of the recipient, even though given up, the tax may be payable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Shoorji Vallabhdas; applies to unilateral relinquishment after accrual.
